guide.introduction:
In this case, it's attached to my electric bike, but it will also work for a normal bicycle as well.

You will need:

  • 1 bicycle
  • 1 rear triangle of a bicycle with the same wheel size as your bike. I used a hacksaw to cut out this triangle from a bike I found in the dump truck.
  • 2 similar cargo racks bolted to both bike and triangle.
  • about 6-7 square feet of 1/2" Baltic Birch plywood.
guide.introduction_rendered:
In this case, it's attached to my electric bike, but it will also work for a normal bicycle as well.

You will need:

  • 1 bicycle
  • 1 rear triangle of a bicycle with the same wheel size as your bike. I used a hacksaw to cut out this triangle from a bike I found in the dump truck.
  • 2 similar cargo racks bolted to both bike and triangle.
  • about 6-7 square feet of 1/2" Baltic Birch plywood.

lines.text: You'll need to buy a couple of decent-quality cargo racks, the kind that has 3 or 4 mounting points.  It helps if they are the same model/brand.
lines.text_raw: You'll need to buy a couple of decent-quality cargo racks, the kind that has 3 or 4 mounting points.  It helps if they are the same model/brand.

lines.text: One of the racks will be mounted to your bike. This particular bicycle is electric-powered, but a regular bicycle will work just fine.
lines.text_raw: One of the racks will be mounted to your bike. This particular bicycle is electric-powered, but a regular bicycle will work just fine.

lines.text: The second rack will be mounted on the rear triangle of a donor bicycle. The rear triangle is cut out from the frame with a hacksaw.
lines.text_raw: The second rack will be mounted on the rear triangle of a donor bicycle. The rear triangle is cut out from the frame with a hacksaw.

lines.text: The sidecar is essentially made by connecting the two cargo racks together.
lines.text_raw: The sidecar is essentially made by connecting the two cargo racks together.

lines.text: The top connecting piece is made from good-quality Baltic Birch, 1/2" thick.  I used a handsaw to cut out the square opening, which was then discarded.
lines.text_raw: The top connecting piece is made from good-quality Baltic Birch, 1/2" thick.  I used a handsaw to cut out the square opening, which was then discarded.

lines.text: Two wings, also made from the same birch plywood, are then cut out and all three pieces are connected via piano hinges.
lines.text_raw: Two wings, also made from the same birch plywood, are then cut out and all three pieces are connected via piano hinges.

lines.text: The wing pieces are then bolted securely to the top of the cargo racks.
lines.text_raw: The wing pieces are then bolted securely to the top of the cargo racks.

lines.text: A crossbar, also from birch ply, is then connected to the lower part of the cargo racks.
lines.text_raw: A crossbar, also from birch ply, is then connected to the lower part of the cargo racks.

lines.text: The crossbar is bolted on using a pair of these handy clamps.  This one has a 1/2" capacity.
lines.text_raw: The crossbar is bolted on using a pair of these handy clamps.  This one has a 1/2" capacity.
